etymology.description: 芥 (mustard) + 蓝/藍 (blue; indigo; used in plant names) = Chinese broccoli.
etymology.interpretation: Names a Brassica oleracea vegetable with thick stems and blue‑green leaves, linked to the mustard family via 芥. In Mandarin it is often pronounced gàilán under Cantonese influence.
etymology.simplification: 蓝 is the simplified form of 藍, reducing strokes; Mainland standardization uses 芥蓝 (also seen as 芥蘭 in traditional contexts).

parts.english: blue; indigo; indigo plant; plant-name morpheme

examples.chinese: 我喜欢清炒芥蓝(我喜歡清炒芥藍)。
粤菜里常用芥蓝配蚝油(粵菜裡常用芥藍配蠔油)。
examples.pinyin: Yuècài lǐ cháng yòng gàilán pèi háoyóu.
examples.english: In Cantonese cuisine, Chinese broccoli is often paired with oyster sauce.

examples.chinese: 农贸市场今天有新鲜芥蓝(農貿市場今天有新鮮芥藍)。
examples.pinyin: Nóngmào shìchǎng jīntiān yǒu xīnxiān gàilán.
examples.english: The farmers’ market has fresh Chinese broccoli today.
